Award.AwardTitle: Dissipative quantum dynamics and response of adsorbates on solid surfaces
Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is development of new theoretical and computational methods to describe the dissipative dynamics and spectra of localized molecular phenomena at solid surfaces, where electronic excitation and atomic rearrangement are induced by collisions or by light absorption. Phenomena of interest are the photoinduced femtosecond dynamics (transient spectra, electron transfer, charge separation, and currents) of excited electrons at a nanostructured semiconductor surface, and the photoisomerization and photodissociation of an adsorbed cluster. Specific applications include Ag clusters adsorbed on Si surfaces, and systems doped with group III and V elements.

The impact of the work includes features fundamental for the design of new materials for photovoltaics and photoelectrodes. Findings are of importance in the utilization of solar energy for electricity and fuels production. The computational methods developed are applicable to the dynamics of electronically excited biomolecules and photobiology (e.g vision, photosynthesis, and radiation damage of tissue). Additionally, these methods are relevant to Raman enhanced spectroscopy of species at surfaces. International conferences are to be organized to integrate research and education of graduate students and to disseminate interdisciplinary research. Research results are incorporated in graduate courses in collaboration with other faculty members at the University of Florida. Mentoring of undergraduate students includes underrepresented groups and training of postdoctoral associates on mathematical aspects of the theory is actively pursued. This award is funded by the Theory Models and Computational Methods program of the Chemistry Division.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main objective of this proposal has been to develop new theoretical and computational methods to describe the optical properties and photoconductivity of chemical materials relevant to the capture of solar energy and its conversion into electricity and fuels. It has combined statistical density operator and ab initio electronic structure methods to account for the dissipative dynamics and spectra of localized molecular phenomena at solid surfaces. Results have been obtained doing large scale computational modeling with newly developed computer codes, starting from the atomic structure of selected  compounds, to discover new materials relevant to photovoltaic applications, and to interpret  measurements of related properties. The work has lead to a breakthrough in the challenging task of calculating properties for excited electronic states of extended  systems. As applications, many results  have been generated for silicon slabs with chosen numbers of layers and with adsorbed silver atom clusters. These compounds can be experimentally realized, and contain readily available and affordable atomic components. Modeling results show large increases in light absorbance and conductivity compared with more standard pure silicon. Conclusions have been presented at numerous national and international conferences and in many publications in refereed journals. The project has also allowed  the training of postdoctoral associates and a graduate student in this important area.  The discovery of new efficient and affordable photovoltaic materials such as done in this project can greatly contribute to economic development and to the health of the environment. The present project is now coming to an end because additional research funds have not been available.
